_prev_prog_3.Description: Prevention Program: An Accidental release Prevention Program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the EPA Risk Management Program Level 3 requirements (40 CFR 68).  The prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents.  Some of the specific activities in the prevention program include: Process Safety Information is accessible at all times.  A hazard review has been conducted as part of the preparations for RMP Compliance.  Written operating procedures are used for training and guiding the work of operators.  Training is provided to all employees that operate the system. A program is in place to properly maintain the system and equipment. Incidents are investigated and actions are taken as part of a continuous improvement program. Routine audits are conducted to assure that safe practices are being followed.  The sterilization process is subject to the Risk Management Program at the facilities designed with extensive safeguards to protect against the accidental release of ethylene oxide.  Examples of safety equipment in place include pressure relief devices, leak detection and alarm systems, door interlock systems, electronic interlock safety systems for sterilization chambers and explosion proof electrical systems.  In addition, process operators receive extensive training in the safe operation of the process; and are required to follow detailed operating procedures to help ensure safety.  Sterigenics also has implemented a mechanical integrity program to monitor the physical condition of process equipment, and replace or repair equipment before it fails.  In the unlikely event of a spill or a release involving ethylene oxide, Sterigenics has developed an emergency response plan providing procedures to be followed to minimize the potential impacts of a fire or release from the facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This RMP formalizes and documents these activities.  Sterigenics is committed to conducting its operations in a safe and responsible manner and to reducing risks to human health and the environment.



Prevention Program 



An Accidental Release Prevention Program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the US EPA Risk Management Program Level 3 requirements (40 CFR 68). The prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents. Some of the specific activities in the prevention program include:



A?A? Process safety information accessible to employees at all times.

A?A? A hazard review was conducted as part of the preparations for RMP compliance.

A?A? Computerized process controls prevent unsafe conditions in the sterilizers.

A?A? Door interlock system.

A?A? Written operating procedures are used for training and guiding the work of operators.

A?A? Training is provided to all employees that operate the system.

A?A? A program is in place to properly maintain the system and equipment.

A?A? Incidents are investigated and actions are taken as part of a continuous improvement effort.

A?A? Routine audits are conducted to assure that safe practices are being followed.

A?A? A thorough Preventative Maintenance program helps ensure equipment is in proper working condition.



The sterilization process subject to the Risk Management Program at the Sterigenics US LLC - Willowbrook facility is designed with extensive safeguards to protect against the accidental release of ethylene oxide. Examples of safety equipment in place include pressure relief devices, leak detection and alarm systems, electronic interlock safety systems for sterilization chambers, door interlock system, and explosion proof electrical systems.  



In addition, process operators receive extensive training in the safe operation of the process, and are required to follow detailed operating procedures to help ensure safety.  SterigenicsI

also has implemented a mechanical integrity program to monitor the physical condition of process equipment, and replace or repair equipment before it fails.



In the unlikely event of a spill or release involving a hazardous material, Sterigenics has developed an emergency response plan providing procedures to be followed to minimize the potential impacts of a fire or release from the facility. 

 

Hazard Evaluation



Under the EPA regulations, Sterigenics is required to evaluate the potential consequences of a worst case release and an alternate release scenario.  These scenarios are included within Section 3 (Hazard Assessment/Offsite Consequences Analysis). 



Five-Year Accident History



Only accidents occurring in the past five years meeting the following requirements must be included:

A?A? The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.

A?A? The release must have caused at least one of the following:

A?A? On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or

A?A? Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.



Sterigenics US LLC- Willowbrook has had one accidental release from the ethylene oxide process within the last five years that meet this definition.  Details are provided below:



1.) Date,Time and duration of accidental release: October 20, 2013 from 4:49pm to 8:15pm (3 hours & 26 minutes).  This reportable release resulted from an emission control scrubber breakdown on October 20th but the released excess emissions were not discovered until about 1:23 pm October 21, 2013.  Upon discovery of the excess emissions, the reportable release was immediately reported to the following agencies:

? Illinois Emergency Management Agency (IEMA) to Paul Kattner (Case # H20131147),

? Du Page County Emergency Response office, and 

? National Response Center (NRC) (Case # 1063583).    



2) The chemical subst

ance released was gaseous ethylene oxide (CAS # 75-21-8). Ethylene Oxide is listed as an extremely hazardous substance (EHS). An estimated 11.9 pounds of EO was released and the reportable quantity is 10 pounds. 



3.)The release from sterilization Chamber B was to atmosphere through the emission stack of the facility's acid scrubber emission control system, which is located about 25 feet above grade. Because of the lengthy release period through an elevated scrubber stack, there are no anticipated adverse health impacts to employees or the general public as a result of this incident. 



4.) The release was caused by failure of an interlock control to prevent process emissions from being routed to the emission control system when it was not functioning properly.  Upon discovering the release of the EO excess emissions from this failed interlock on Chamber B, the facility ceased processing in Chamber B and initiated an immediate investigation into why the interlock failed to prevent these excess emissions.  Chamber B was not restarted until the interlock system was repaired and tested with a documented protocol to confirm its proper operation.



Emergency Response Plan



The RMP regulations require that "response actions be coordinated with local emergency planning and response agencies" (40 CFR 68.12(b)(3)).   Emergency response activities at the Sterigenics EO - Willowbrook facility are coordinated with the Tri-State Fire Department and the State of Illinois Emergency Response ESDA.



Depending on the quantity and chemical involved in a "reportable spill," Sterigenics US LLC - Willowbrook also notifies certain local, state, and federal emergency planning and response agencies. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Safety and Emergency Preparedness is a part of Sterigenics' activities.  Exposure risks to employees and the public have been minimized through ongoing inspections and regulatory requirements.  At this time, no further improvements have been ident

ified.  

Chemical-Specific Safety



Ethylene oxide is stored in an outdoor staging area that is cool, dry, well-ventilated and away from incompatible chemicals and sources of ignition.  Storage containers are insulated and have pressure relief valves. Lower explosive limit (LEL) sensors are located near areas of potential leaks including gas storage areas, gas charging areas, and chamber doors that will alarm with an audible alarm in the event of a major leak from the ethylene oxide cylinders or process.
